postsData.name:
Jen E Miller
Jen E Miller
postsData.content:
This week included solving tons of problems (okay, not literally tons, but a lot). 

And it's really got me thinking about how teaching strong problem solving skills in the workplace is paramount.

Are you giving problem solving skill development the attention it deserves?

Think about this simple scenario.

You've begun preparing a meal in your own kitchen and realize you don't have access to a main tool you are used to using for that recipe (a can opener, a strainer, a measuring cup, etc.).

How would you handle the situation? Could you truly solve in the moment with creativity and nimbleness without giving up, or asking Siri to weigh in as well? Challenge yourself to really think about ways to handle such a simple scenario without borrowing from a neighbor or running out and buying what you think you need.

And here's the bigger question, could those reporting to you figure out ways to handle the situation without asking for advice from you, others, or the Internet?

Now think of day to day problems that come up all of the time in the line of work you are in - how do you and your team navigate? Are you confident and empowered to solve what needs to be solved? What could be different or better?

comments.commentText:
strong problem-solving skills truly transform teams into powerhouses. have you tried creative exercises to boost your team's confidence?  
#problemsolving

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Empowering teams to think creatively during challenges fosters resilience. How do you encourage this in your workplace?

postsData.content:
The dream is realâ€”but it requires action. 

At 19, I had a steady job as a bellman at the Boston Harbor Hotel. Great benefits, a 401Kâ€”it was the dream for many. But not for me. I stood there, day after day, knowing, 'This isnâ€™t where I belong.'

So I made a choice. I got up, walked out, and pursued what I truly wanted: a career in the fight business.

It wasnâ€™t easy, but it was worth it. If youâ€™re in a place that doesnâ€™t feel like you, maybe itâ€™s time to take that step too.



Sharing this could inspire someone to make their move. Hit repost and help someone today."

postsData.name:
SÃ¶ren MÃ¼ller
SÃ¶ren MÃ¼ller
postsData.content:
Chickens are amazing, but when we are trying to enjoy a nice peaceful moment in a farm's countryside, the loud and incessant clucking of chickens can quickly shatter the tranquility.

But it's a beautiful language of freedom that should be appreciated either way.

Chickens communicate with each other through a variety of clucks, crows, and chirps, each sound carrying a different meaning, and it's a beautiful language of freedom that should be appreciated.

The intense communication doesnâ€™t mean they donâ€™t appreciate silence, they wake up gradually, gradually adjusting to the light as day breaks, but for chickens in modern factory farms, the experience is vastly different.

In these unnatural environments we leave adverse impacts on all living things that share the ecosystem. We scared all the silence away too, and the reactions take on different forms of noise, often in ways that we do not anticipate.

If we had considered it as a shared responsibility and treated other living beings as fellow travelers on this planet, the pains of today wouldn't be so much.

When we understand that our actions have far-reaching consequences, we start working towards creating a world where every being has the space and freedom to thrive, and where the balance of nature is maintained.

Achieving that begins with awareness of how our everyday decisions affect the environment and a promise to do better for ourselves and for the generations that will come after us.

comments.commentText: The loud and incessant clucking of chickens is part of nature and we just have to appreciate it. Sometimes, nature is quiet. Sometimes, it's loud. It's all that that makes it beautiful.
Every day we make choices in our lives that affect the environment, the animals, humans, climate and other species.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing the beauty in all forms of life and fostering harmony in our ecosystems is essential for a sustainable future. ğŸŒğŸ”

postsData.name:
Pratham Mishra
Pratham Mishra
postsData.content:
Grateful to Attend the SCAN IIT Bombay Annual Symposium 2025 
I feel truly blessed to have been part of the SCAN Annual Symposium 2025: Dementia and Neurodegeneration at IIT Bombay. It was an exceptional opportunity to learn from some of the most inspiring researchers and practitioners in the field of neurodegenerative diseases.
Each speaker shared invaluable insights that broadened my understanding and encouraged me to think more critically about the challenges in this field:

Prof. Dr.Sir, Professor-in-charge SCAN, for his visionary leadership and dedication to fostering collaboration in neurodegenerative research.

Dr. Sangeeta Ravat Ma'am (KEM Hospital, Mumbai), for her expertise in clinical diagnostics and strategies for patient care.

Prof.Ma'am (TIFR, Mumbai), for her enlightening talk on fundamental neuroscience and its role in understanding brain disorders.

Prof.Sir (IIT Madras), for his innovative work in assistive technologies to improve patient outcomes.

Prof. Rishikesh Narayanan Sir (IISc, Bangalore), for his contributions to advancing our understanding of neural networks and mechanisms underlying neurodegeneration.

Prof. T.V. Sekher Sir (IIPS, Mumbai), for his valuable perspective on public health and the societal impact of aging and dementia.

Ms.Ma'am (Dementia in India Alliance, Bangalore), for her inspiring advocacy and work in dementia care across India.

Dr. Amitabha Majumdar Sir (NCCS, Pune), for his impactful research into the cellular and molecular biology of neurodegeneration.

Prof. Dr.Sir (IIT Bombay), for his pioneering contributions to diagnostic biomarkers and therapeutic advancements.

The discussions ranged across diverse topics such as biomarkers, clinical diagnostics, neuropsychology, palliative care, and fundamental neuroscience, each of which was thoughtfully explored. I came away with a wealth of knowledge and a deep sense of inspiration.

I am sincerely thankful to Prof.Sir and the entireteam for organizing such a meaningful event and creating a space for collaboration and learning. The efforts of all the speakers and researchers are paving the way for breakthroughs that hold immense promise for the future.
I look forward to applying the knowledge I have gained and contributing to this critical field in whatever way I can.
postsData.commentAdded: What an enriching experience! Your insights on neurodegenerative diseases are inspiring, and its wonderful to see such collaboration in action! ğŸŒŸ

postsData.name:
Cristian Mudure
Cristian Mudure
postsData.content:
â€œCan we get 2 additional licenses for free? It doesnâ€™t cost you anything.â€

This is a sentence SaaS companies hear often, and it highlights a common misunderstanding about the cost structure of SaaS products. Hereâ€™s why this request is problematic:

1. Perceived vs. Actual Costs:
While SaaS products operate in the cloud, and thereâ€™s no physical product involved, additional licenses still incur indirect costs. For instance, more users might increase server load, customer support demands, or other operational expenses. Even if marginal costs are low, resources like maintenance, infrastructure, and scalability all play a role.

2. Value vs. Cost:
Licenses arenâ€™t priced purely based on cost to the company; theyâ€™re priced based on the value the software delivers to the customer. Granting free licenses diminishes the perceived value of the product and sets a precedent for discount expectations.

3. Scalability and Fairness:
If SaaS companies start handing out additional licenses for free to every customer who asks, it would disrupt their revenue model. Customers paying full price for their licenses might see this as unfair, leading to dissatisfaction or churn.

4. Long-Term Support Implications:
Every additional license represents another user that may require training, onboarding, and support. These resources arenâ€™t free, even if the software is already built.

5. Addressing the Mindset:
Customers often see SaaS as an infinite resource because itâ€™s digital. Educating users about why licenses are priced as they areâ€”and the broader value SaaS products deliverâ€”can help bridge this gap in understanding.

comments.commentText: May I have second Mercedes for free? I just bought one and this should be covered by your margin... Serious? Strange that if it comes to intellectual property many people think that immaterial products have less commercial value. I just remind the discussion on copyrights of movies, songs and other pieces of art.
Fabian Henschel Perception is gradually changing
Iâ€™ve seen this scenario too and I can agree more with Cristian Mudure points. A few confuse SaaS with SaaC (C for charity)
Pablo Asensio part of the game

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Educating customers on the true value of SaaS licenses is crucial for mutual growth and understanding. Thanks for sharing!

postsData.content:
I lived in Russia my first 6 years of life. 


We did not have snow days and school closings.

It always snowed and was cold AF.

You know what we called it?

Winter.

If there was an impending missile strike or nuclear attack . . .

That was a delayed opening.

We had warm jackets, hats and chains on tires.

Why does everyone freak out about weather in the US?

Yours truthfully,

postsData.name:
Dan Goodman
Dan Goodman
postsData.content:
PIP or Severance? I say neither. Don't let them force you to make the decision. They want you to leave, let them initiate it. 

So many employees are being blindsided with the question and forced to answer it. Two bad choices that the employee wants no part of either. Yet are being pressured with one or two days to decide.

Important decisions about their livelihoods and ability to support their families yet intentionally not given the full picture of the ramifications of each decision.

Just told how miserable and unfair the PIP will be. They'll describe it so that any reasonable person will not want to go through it.

Instead of having to endure a PIP they describe with an inevitable outcome, they offer you a severance. Most people think of a severance being associated with a termination. When employees are terminated they typically are eligible for unemployment.

However when the employee initiates the termination by choosing the severance, they have in essence resigned and are not eligible for unemployment.

It is shameful that the employer intentionally withholds this information while pressuring the employee to make a decision based on misinformation or lack of information. It is despicable.

Some employees are being tricked into a severance worth as little as a few thousand dollars and giving up their rights to unemployment that in some states could be worth up to $30,000.

Below is a DM from someone who found out the hard way. Don't make the same mistake.

comments.commentText: Thanks for the repost William Lutz, MPA, PMP. I appreciate it.

postsData.commentAdded: This is a crucial discussion! Employees deserve transparency and support during such tough decisions. Knowledge is power. ğŸŒŸ
